message.content:
cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.IR, cs.DS, cs.CE 

This paper deals with learning from historical data in a contextual bandit setting, which is a problem commonly studied in the machine learning community. The paper proposes a solution that allows learning from nonrandom exploration data, which is a novel contribution. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.LG (Machine Learning), followed by cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) and cs.IR (Information Retrieval), as these sub-categories are closely related to the problem addressed in the paper. Additionally, the paper uses real-world data obtained from Yahoo!, which suggests that it may also be relevant to cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) and cs.CE (Computational Engineering, Finance, and Science).
